New Records: Texas improved to a record 10-0 on the road this postseason.
Rangers batters became the first team in Series history with consecutive five-run innings.
Corey Seager is the first shortstop with three Series homers.
Key Match Events: Marcus Semien’s two-run triple and three-run homer powered Texas to a 10-run lead by the third inning.
Corey Seager hit another long home run.
Jonah Heim added an eighth-inning shot.
Lourdes Gurriel Jr. hit a three-run homer in the eighth.
Ketel Marte extended his record postseason hitting streak to 20 games.
Pre-Game Insights: Adolis García gathered Texas Rangers hitters and told them his World Series was over due to injury.
Max Scherzer was also finished due to injury.
Travis Jankowski recalled García saying, 'Pull together guys. Let’s finish it!'
Nathan Eovaldi tries to clinch the third all-wild card Series on Wednesday night against Zac Gallen in a rematch of Game 1 starters.
Post-Match Reflections: Corey Seager said of García, 'That took a lot of guts for him to come out there and speak. He was vulnerable. He wants to be out there. He told us he loved us.'
Marcus Semien said, 'We’ve got our top guy on the mound now. He’s a guy who’s been waiting for this moment the entire year.'
Diamondbacks manager Torey Lovullo said, 'This was nothing that we saw coming. It all came unraveled on us there in a matter of two innings.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: There was a festive mood at Chase Field, where the roof was open for the second straight night and some fans arrived in Halloween costumes.
Rangers players gathered with their families at the team hotel at 10 a.m. About two dozen children were in costume.
Others: Andrew Heaney earned the win by allowing four hits in five innings.
Six relievers followed, with closer José Leclerc getting the final out.
García (left oblique) and Scherzer (back spasm) were removed from the Texas roster a day after getting hurt.
Seager appeared to twist one or both ankles on his home run swing but said he was fine.
Rangers rookie Evan Carter was hit on the right pinkie by a pitch in the ninth.
